    HYP: in an emergency call , the professor admitted he shot his girlfriend

    HYP: during a call to the emergency line with a shaking voice , Professor Shannon Lamb admitted to police that he had shot his girlfriend and it was necessary for them to come to their home .

    HYP: lamb has presided over that his `` sweet dog '' was alive and probably distraught , and that contacts on the dead woman 's family can be found on her phone .

    HYP: details that were published by investigators on the state and students and staff who knew him together created an image of a talented but probably troubled teacher .

    HYP: 46 percent say they keep an open backdoor for change between candidates .

    HYP: yet Trump is the current strongest opponent of his outsider 's fellow neurosurgeon Ben Carson , but voters who consider their opinion final would go twice more likely to vote for Trump .

    HYP: 6 out of 10 Republicans reportedly agree with Trump on immigration issues .

    HYP: indeed , ever since Donald Trump called immigrants from Mexico `` thugs '' in the announcement speech of his campaign , immigration still stands as the main and central topic of the 2016 conversation .

    HYP: some worry that Trump 's drudgery will lure key Hispanic voters away from the Republican Party and damage to rebranding .

    HYP: but according to a new Monday poll by ABC / Post , six out of 10 Republicans claim to agree with Trump on immigration issues .

    HYP: as long as immigration remains in the spotlight , Donald Trump will remain as well .

    HYP: frustration at the government is reaching new highs .

    HYP: Donald Trump and Ben Carson now receive roughly half of the support from Republican voters , especially given their status as outsiders .

    HYP: six of the 10 Republicans in the new Monday 's ABC / Post poll say they want a political outsider rather than someone with government experience .

    HYP: and they are also very angry at Washington .

    HYP: the House has supported a greater share of the state from the levy on coal .

    HYP: the Czech Republic will acquire more than 400 million .

    HYP: Minister John Mousdek ( SSD ) has promised MPs that it will raise money in addition to both the Treasury and the budgets of the municipalities .


  149.     HYP: the state 's share will rise to 67 per cent , while the municipality 's share will be reduced from the current 75 per cent to 33 per cent .

    HYP: the draft is also changing the way to calculate reimbursement for the minerals that companies extract .

    HYP: the change in fees for mining operations is to bring to the Treasury about $ 427 million more than in 2013 .

    HYP: the government 's revenue budgets are to have a neutral impact , according to the government , because the fee is to be higher .

    HYP: in the previous year , commuters received from fees of about $ 450 million and a state budget of $ 150 million .

    HYP: from the extraction of brown coal , there were around 200 million kronor and a state of 66 million kronor .

    HYP: the amendment also envisages an increase in the amount of recovery in excess of EUR 1000 per hectare per hectare per year .

    HYP: the income from these remittances remains in its entirety .

    HYP: industry Minister John Mousdek ( SSD ) told MPs that commuters would gain a year instead of 14 million to 100 million kronor .

    HYP: the amount of mining fees will no longer be determined by the law , but it is set by the government by its regulation .

    HYP: the payment shall be recalculated as a product of the amount of the mineral extracted and the rates for the different types of mineral .

    HYP: according to the Government , the reason for the change is that of a flexible response to the current economic situation .

    HYP: the fees are received only by municipalities whose territories are affected .

    HYP: in the case of deep-sea coal mining , there will be three-quarters of the community 's money and a quarter of the state .

    HYP: the same ratio will be in the case of radioactive rock extraction .

    HYP: part of the money that the state will collect on mining fees will be assigned .

    HYP: for example , 28 percent will have to go to repair the damage after mining or to provide a year-long rescue service .

    HYP: the draft was criticised by opposition MPs , who argued in particular that it would hurt communities affected by mining and the region .

    HYP: email your photos and videos to yourpics @ bbc.co.uk

    HYP: you can also upload your videos or photos .


  265. REF: we will publish your name as you provide it , unless you ask us not to .

    HYP: we will publish your name as you provide it ( if you do n't ask us for secrecy ) .

    HYP: for example , it is the opinion of the environmental authorities .

  321. REF: Metcash launches grassroots campaign to fight Aldi incursion

    HYP: Metcash is trying to protect its IGA stores from the onslaught of Aldi in South and Western Australia .

    HYP: Metcash launches campaign in the countryside to fight the Aldi invasion


  324. REF: as Aldi prepares to open two distribution centres and the first of as many as 120 stores in South Australia and Western Australia early next year , Metcash and IGA supermarkets are strengthening relationships with local food suppliers and building the IGA brand through mainstream and social media marketing and events such as the Adelaide show .

    HYP: IGA traders and suppliers are joining with brands like them on Dunsborough-based ice cream maker Simmo 's offering tasting in the IGA stores and store owners selling discounted tickets to the Australian Football League to local customers .

    HYP: Metcash is expected to release more details of its defence strategy on September 29 , when the retailer 's food , alcohol and hardware will celebrate its annual investor 's strategic day .


  327. REF: there is much at stake , as South Australia and Western Australia account for almost 30 per cent of Metcash 's IGA store footprint and generate higher profit margins than Metcash 's IGA network in the eastern states .

    HYP: there is a lot at stake because South and Western Australia represent almost 30 per cent of Metcash 's IGA business actions and generate a higher turnover than the Metcash IGA network in the eastern states .


  328. REF: South Australian and Western Australian shoppers are notoriously parochial and IGA retailers enjoy a much stronger market share than they do in NSW , Victoria and Queensland - more than 30 per cent in SA and 24 per cent in WA compared with around 14 per cent in the Eastern states .

    HYP: customers in South and Western Australia are notoriously provincial and business IGA is taking a much stronger market share than in NSW , Victoria and Queensland - more than 30 per cent in SA and 24 per cent in WA compared to around 14 per cent in the eastern states .


  329. REF: however , analysts such as Morgan Stanley believe Aldi will snare around 5 per cent of the grocery market in these two states within 12 months of opening its first stores , taking sales from all existing players but mainly from independent retailers .

    HYP: in any case , analysts such as Morgan Stanley believe Aldi will tap into 5 per cent of the food market in these two states during the 12 months since the opening of the first deals that took sales from all existing players , but mainly independent retailers .


  330. REF: in a report this week , Morgan Stanley analyst Tom Kierath estimated that IGA retailers could lose $ 360 million a year in sales and Metcash $ 250 million by the end of 2016 .

    HYP: this week in its report , Morgan Stanley , Tom Kierath , estimated that the retail of IGA could lose $ 360 million on annual sales and Metcash $ 250 million at the end of 2016 .


  331. REF: this forecast is based on the assumption that Aldi opens 25 stores in SA and 30 in WA next year , generating sales of $ 500 million and $ 600 million in each market .

    HYP: that prediction is based on the assumption that Aldi will open 25 stores in South Australia and 30 in the West over the next year , and will generate sales of $ 500 and $ 600 million in individual markets .


  332. REF: the loss of food and grocery sales and volumes on Metcash 's high fixed-cost base could cost Metcash around $ 13 million in earnings before interest and tax , Mr Kierath said .

    HYP: the loss of food sales and volumes at a fixed price basis Metcash could cost him around $ 13 million in pre-tax returns , Mr Kierath confirmed .


  333. REF: at the same time , Metcash is losing market share in the eastern states , mainly to Aldi and Coles , even though a recent Roy Morgan survey found IGA shoppers were most loyal .

    HYP: at the same time , Metcash loses its share of markets in the eastern states , mainly to Aldi and Coles , although the latest poll by Roy Morgan found that shoppers in the IGA were most loyal .


  334. REF: Morgan Stanley believes Metcash 's food and grocery sales will fall 3.8 per cent in 2016 , 4.1 per cent in 2017 and 2.1 per cent in 2018 , reducing its market share from 14 per cent in 2015 to 10.3 per cent by 2020 .

    HYP: Morgan Stanley thinks sales of food Metcash will drop by 3.8 percent in 2016 , 4.1 percent in 2017 and 2.1 percent in 2018 , and its market share will fall from 14 percent in 2015 to 10.3 percent by 2020 .


  335. REF: last week , leading fund manager Hamish Douglass , the founder of Magellan Financial Group , told a business lunch in Melbourne that Metcash could `` highly , probably disappear within a decade .

    HYP: last week , fund manager Hamish Douglass , founder of the financial group Magellan , said trading lunches in Melbourne could be `` highly likely to disappear within a decade .

    HYP: Metcash refused to publicly respond to Douglas 's comment .


  337. REF: but it is understood that a Metcash board member contacted Mr Douglass last week .

    HYP: but it is known that a board member of Metcash contacted Douglas last week .


  338. REF: IGA 's market share has fallen from 18 per cent to 14 per cent since 2010 and earnings from Metcash 's food and grocery business , which supplies about 1200 IGA retailers , have fallen 43 per cent since 2012 , reflecting operating deleverage as sales and margins come under pressure .

    HYP: the market share of the IGA has dropped from 18 per cent to 14 per cent since 2010 , and earnings from the food store Metcash , which delivers about 1200 retailers IGA , have fallen by 43 per cent since 2012 , reflecting the operational development of the change in speculations , as sales and revenues are under pressure .


  339. REF: however , the wholesaler is fighting back , investing more than $ 150 million a year matching shelf prices at Coles and Woolworths on hundreds of products each week , helping IGA retailers refurbish stores by adding faster-growing fresh food , and rolling out a better range of private label groceries .

    HYP: however , the wholesaler has switched to counter-attack and invest more than $ 150 million a year to meet the pulse prices in Coles and Woolworths on hundreds of products each week and helps so retailers IGA re-equip the business by adding fast-growing food and news from the privateers .

    HYP: the executive director of Metcash , Ian Morrice , argues that price-comparison programs and dovish business will catch up with the slump and hopes that wholesale returns will return to basic profit growth of profit in 2017 for the first time in four years .

  349. REF: he did break a racquet when he lost when he cramped in the US , but he 's not the first player to break a racquet out of frustration with himself , and I know Thanasi well enough to know he would n't be proud of that .

  350. REF: but , really , he 's handled himself extremely well , in pretty provocative circumstances in the US with Harrison and so on , and I think he deserves a lot of credit .

    HYP: but he really controlled himself very well because he was in the US subject to a very provocative circumstance because of Harrison and so on , so I think he deserves great credit .

    HYP: he has a fantastic team around him , he also has a great family around him and I think he has been treated somewhat hard with him .


  352. REF: he 's a very mature 19-year-old , he works very hard , and he fits in with the team and so on , he has n't ever had an issue with the other players , he 's well respected in the locker room , he trains hard , he 's in great shape , he 's a very stable and mature young guy and I just think he deserves to be judged on his own merits .

    HYP: he 's a very grown-up 19-year-old man , he works very hard and he fits well into the team and so on , he 's never had a problem with the other players , he 's been very respected in the dressing room , he 's been in amazing shape , he 's a very stable and mature young kid and I just think he deserves to be judged on his own merits .

  354. REF: `` First of all we want the team to be completely focused on the tie and not all the controversy around [ Kyrgios ] , '' Healy said .

    HYP: `` First of all we want our team to be absolutely focused on the game and not on all the controversy that around him [ Kyrgios ] was created , '' Healy says .


  355. REF: and I think Nick , he 's risen very quickly , as people like Federer and Murray have pointed out , he 's growing up in the public eye and he 's made some terrible errors and deserves all the criticism he gets , but we 're trying to support him , we 're trying to help him understand the consequences of his actions , and some time out of the limelight where he can just reflect on that I think is appropriate and it 's best for the team and it 's best for him .

  356. REF: Europe migrant crisis : Hungary declares emergency , seals border , detains migrants

    HYP: European migration crisis : Hungary declares emergency , closing borders and holding migrants


  357. REF: declaring a state of emergency , Hungary sealed off its southern border with Serbia on Tuesday and detained those trying to enter illegally , aiming to shut down the flow of migrants pouring in .

    HYP: following the announcement of the state of emergency , Hungary closed its southern border with Serbia on Tuesday and detained those who attempted its illegal crossing to stop the influx of migrants .


  358. REF: chaos ensued at the border , as hundreds of migrants piled up in a no man 's land , and Serbian officials reacted with outrage .

    HYP: there was chaos on the border , while hundreds of migrants accumulated in the country of no one and the Serbian authorities reacted with outrage .


  359. REF: stuck for an unknown amount of time on a strip of road between the two countries ' checkpoints , those fleeing violence in their homelands pitched tents and settled in .

    HYP: those who have been stranded for an unknown time on the strips of the country between two states are those fleeing violence in their native countries , building their tents and settling down .


  360. REF: but frustrations were on the rise .

    HYP: but there comes a sense of frustration .


  361. REF: as a police helicopter hovered above , migrants chanted `` Open the border ! '' and shouted insults at Hungarian riot police .

    HYP: when a helicopter flies over them , the migrants together call `` Open the border ! '' And give the order of the Hungarian police force .


  362. REF: some refused food and water in protest .

    HYP: some in protest refuse food and water .


  363. REF: Serbia 's foreign minister declared it was `` unacceptable '' that migrants were being sent back from Hungary while more and more were arriving from Macedonia and Greece .

    HYP: Serbia 's foreign minister claims it was `` unacceptable '' for refugees to be sent back from Hungary , while increasingly arriving from Macedonia and Greece .


  364. REF: ( Serbia ) wants to be part of the solution , not collateral damage .

    HYP: ( Serbia ) wants to be part of the solution , not just indirect harm .


  365. REF: there will have to be talks in the coming days with Brussels and other countries , '' Ivica Dacic said in Prague .

    HYP: it will need to be discussed with Brussels and other countries in the next few days , `` says Ivica Dacic in Prague .


  366. REF: the turmoil at the Hungarian-Serbian border came a day after the 28-nation bloc failed to come up with a united immigration policy at a contentious meeting in Brussels .

    HYP: the unrest on the Hungarian-Serbian border came a day after a block of 28 states did not come up with a unified immigration policy on continuing meetings in Brussels .


  367. REF: the ministers did agree to share responsibility for 40,000 people seeking refuge in overwhelmed Italy and Greece and spoke hopefully of reaching an eventual deal - next month or by the end of the year - on which EU nations would take 120,000 more refugees , including some from Hungary .

    HYP: ministers agreed to share the responsibility for the 40,000 people seeking protection in the surprise Italy and Greece , and spoke with the hope of reaching a possible deal next month or the end of the year that the EU nations would accept more than 120,000 more refugees , including Hungary .


  368. REF: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Austria called Tuesday for a special European Union summit next week to discuss the continent 's immigration crisis .

    HYP: German federal chancellor Angela Merkel and Austria on Tuesday called a special EU European summit next week to discuss the continental refugee crisis .


  369. REF: Hungary , however , was not pinning its hopes on any action soon from Brussels or its neighbors .

    HYP: nevertheless , Hungary has not committed its hopes to Brussels or its neighbors .


  370. REF: Tuesday 's state of emergency in two southern regions gave authorities greater powers to deal with the crisis , allowing them to shut down roads and speed up asylum court cases .

    HYP: Tuesday 's state of danger in the two southern regions gave the authority a greater authority to tackle the crisis and allowed them to close the roads and accelerate judicial cases of discussing asylum .


  371. REF: meanwhile , Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto said his country is also planning to build a razor-wire fence along part of its border with Romania to stop the flow of migrants through the country , now that it has finished a fence on the Serbian border .

    HYP: meanwhile , Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto said his country was also planning to build a barbed-wire fence along the border with Romania to stop refugees trying to cross their country when the fence is now completed on the Serbian border .


  372. REF: CBS News correspondent Charlie D'Agata reported that even prison inmates were enlisted in the race to finish the razor wire fence between Hungary and Serbia .

    HYP: CBS News Corrections Charlie D'Agata reported that even the inmates were on the list of those who helped stretch the barbed wire between Hungary and Serbia .


  373. REF: in the last few months , Hungary has become a major bottleneck and entry point into the European Union for migrants , many of them war refugees from Syria and elsewhere in the Middle East .

    HYP: in recent months , Hungary has become the main weakness and entry point into the European Union for Refugees , many of whom have fled from Syrie and other Middle Eastern countries .

    HYP: Prime Minister Viktor Orban , however , insisted that most of them are economic migrants who go for better life and not war refugees seeking protection , a view that is clearly different from other EU states , including Germany .

    HYP: the new laws that came into force at midnight in Hungary are now criminalizing a breach of the 4-metre fence that the government has placed on the southern border with Serbia , and also sets longer jail terms for those who illegally convert refugees .

    HYP: `` Thanks to the situation caused by the mass migration , the Hungarian government is announcing the state of emergency , '' a spokesman for the government of Zoltan Kovacs in the southern city of Szeged told reporters .

    HYP: in this we are absolutely clear : illegal crossing the border is a crime .

    HYP: technically , parliament must still approve the deployment of the military expected next week , but reporters in the Associated Press on the border observed the heavily armed army with vehicles and dogs for several days .

    HYP: Gyorgy Bakondi , an adviser to Orban for the home defence , said the authorities caught 45 people who tried to cross the border and 15 were caught already in the state 's territory .

    HYP: they have penetrated the fence and are now in police custody charged with committing offences under new laws .

    HYP: authorities quickly let the fence fix .

  480. REF: more specifically , the market over the past 35 years or so is most often up sharply - about 14 percent - heading into the rate hike , fairly flat in the 250 days after ( average gain of 2.6 percent ) then back to normal once 500 days have passed , with average return in the past six cycles of 14.4 percent , according to a recent analysis Bob Doll , chief equity strategist at Nuveen Asset Management , posted on Barron 's .

    HYP: in fact , the market for the last roughly 35 years is often the most - about 14 per cent - heading into a rate rise in relatively flat in 250 days ( average gains of 2.6 per cent ) , and then returning to normal after 500 days , with the average yield of 14.4 per cent from the last six cycles , according to a recent analysis of Bob Dolla , chief equity strategist at Nuveen Asset Management , published on Barron .

    HYP: Deutsche said the impact on stocks tends to become more pronounced later in the rate hike cycle , and the return is beginning to decrease .

    HYP: recession is a fact of economic life , but raising rates often helps .

    HYP: most notable is that gross domestic product close to its lowest point in history in raising the Fed rate .

  489. REF: while many strategists and economists believe the FOMC could approve a hike at this meeting , futures trading indicates just a 25 percent probability .

    HYP: while many strategists and economists believe that the FOMC could approve an increase at this meeting , future trading indicates only a 25 per cent probability .


  490. REF: `` In our study since 1950 , all hiking cycles to date have been in a super cycle of increasing leverage with GDP eclipsing prerecession peaks very quickly post the recovery commencing , '' the report said .

    HYP: `` In our study since 1950 , all of the increase cycles so far have been in a super cycle of increasing leverage with GDP covering the peaks of the beginning of the recession very quickly after the counting recovery , '' it writes in the report .


  491. REF: by contrast this has been a uniquely slow recovery from what was the worst recession in the sample period .

    HYP: on the contrary , this was clearly a slow recovery from the worst recession in the sampling period .


  492. REF: the current cycle is by far the longest the Fed has waited since the end of the last recession ; the record had been 35 months , and this is 74 months and counting .

    HYP: the current cycle is by far the longest of those that the Fed has expected since the end of the last recession ; the record has been 35 months , we are now at 74 months and still continuing .


  493. REF: fixed income also has been volatile as the market anticipates a rate hike , and the pattern is somewhat similar to what equities experience .

    HYP: the fixed yield was also volatile as the market expects an increase in rates , and the pattern is somewhat similar to what the stock is experiencing .


  494. REF: the principal difference is that the impact happens faster in bonds than stocks when the Fed changes course in policy .

    HYP: the key difference is that the impact is more rapid on bonds than in stocks when the Fed changes the direction of policy .


  495. REF: for bonds , it does seem yields change direction immediately as the first hike/cut in the cycle arrives .

    HYP: for bonds , yields appear to change direction immediately after the first arrival of the increase / reduction cycle .


  496. REF: at the end of the hiking cycle bond yields fall immediately , '' Deutsche said .

    HYP: at the end of the cycle of increasing bond yields , they fall immediately , `` Deutsche said .

    HYP: the strategists of Charles Schwab believe that an increase in rates will cause returns between long- and short-dated bonds , equal to a curve .

    HYP: high-yield bonds often work better in this climate , though `` we are still cautious about straining the yield , '' Kathy Jones , a fixed-income analyst at Schwab , said in her analysis .

    HYP: interestingly , Jones thinks the markets are already adjusting to Fed policy expectations .

    HYP: `` In addition to the strength of the dollar and the decline in inflation expectations , there are few signs that the market has adjusted to the outlook for tighter monetary policy , '' she wrote .

    HYP: short-term interest rates are up , the yield curve is flat , the credit margin has widened , and volatility has increased - all market characteristics when the Fed tightens policy .

    HYP: generally speaking , companies that carry out most of their business in the US will win interest rates after raising interest rates , and local products become more attractive .

    HYP: multinationals with lots of debt are going to get worse as the rising dollar will make their products more expensive in the world market and their debt will also be larger .

    HYP: debt becomes a big problem .

    HYP: in the coming year , pensions should rise to an average of about a century .

    HYP: even those who died in December would be able to get a pension before paying for it .

    HYP: this year the pension is 41.5 per cent gross salary , next year it should be 40.5 per cent .

    HYP: in the kitchen , it features a unique characteristic of raising the natural flavour of the meal .

    HYP: it also is suitable for frying and grilling because it has a high degree of combustion , up to 216 C .

    HYP: yet all of this is not enough : the development of the disease can fundamentally affect the patient itself .

    HYP: the more he actively struggles with the disease , the longer he can work and may not fundamentally change the style of his life .


  790. REF: as highlighted by doctors , passivity in patients leaves room for the activity of the disease .

    HYP: as doctors warn , the passivity of the sick releases room for disease activity .


  791. REF: for example , it has been proved that regular movement significantly delays the time when the patient requires a compensatory aid , for example a walking-stick .

    HYP: for example , it has been shown that the regular movement has significantly delayed the time when the sick needs some compensatory aid , such as a cane .


  792. REF: it is important for patients and those around them to not believe various myths , for example that the disease will automatically lead to them being confined to a wheelchair .

    HYP: importantly , patients and their surroundings are not subject to different myths , for example , that the disease automatically leads them to end up in a trolley .

    HYP: this is because we have medicines for multiple sclerosis in an inflammatory stage , when the neurodegeneration process is not so strong .

  1024. REF: `` Set in the walled city of Thneed-Ville , where all nature has gone and even the air is a commodity , a boy named Ted hopes to win the heart of his dream girl , Audrey , by fulfilling her wish to see a real tree , '' it reads , chronicling a love interest unknown to Dr Seuss , real name Theodor Seuss Geisel , who died in 1991 .

    HYP: `` In the city of Thneed-Ville surrounded by walls , where all nature has ceased to exist , and even the air is a commodity , a boy named Ted hopes to win the heart of a girl of his dreams , Audrey , by fulfilling her wish to see the real tree , '' is the brief content of a book that records the object of love unknown to Dr Seuss , whose real name was Theodor Seuss Geisel , who died in 1991 .


  1025. REF: if that was n't suspicious enough , Cameron 's submitted text reads in part like a plot summary of the Lorax film provided on the Internet Movie Database website , which begins : `` In the walled city of Thneed-Ville , where everything is artificial and even the air is a commodity , a boy named Ted hopes to win the heart of his dream girl , Audrey . ''

    HYP: as though it was n't suspicious enough , the text delivered by Cameron reads like a summary lift of the Lorax film , which is located on the Internet Movie Database , and begins with the words , `` In the city of Thneed-Ville walled-in , where all nature has ceased to exist , and even the air is a commodity , a boy called Ted hopes to win the heart of a girl of your dreams , Audrey . ''


  1026. REF: given he is an avowedly hands-on parent , it seems unlikely Cameron is so unfamiliar with the book 's plot , in which a young unnamed boy hears how the local environment was devastated by the avaricious , tree-chopping , thneed-knitting Once-ler , despite the protests of the eponymous Lorax , a squat , moustachioed creature who `` speaks for the trees . ''

    HYP: because he was an openly practical parent , it seems unlikely that Cameron would not have met the children of the book , where the unnamed young man would know the local nature of the devastation , the trees felled by industrialist Once-ler , who , despite the protests of the titular Lorax , a crouching , moustachioed creature who `` speaks for the trees . ''

  1113. ''

    HYP: they indicate that the public could expect a PHE statement that reads `` the current best guess is that e-cigarettes are around 95 % less harmful than smoking '' are based on a detailed examination of evidence and modelling .


  1115.     HYP: in fact , this conclusion comes from one meeting of 12 people called to draw up the analysis of the multi-criterion ( MCDA ) decision to synthesize their views on the damage associated with the different products containing nicotine ; the results of the negotiations were summarised in the research report .

    HYP: McKee and Capewell said one sponsor of this meeting was a company called EuroSwiss Health , whose CEO had reportedly already received funding from British American Tobacco for independent studies .

    HYP: it also approved the mandate of public health BAT in the sustainability report , it says .

    HYP: a meeting in PHE also took part in the tobacco leadership .

    HYP: however , none of these links or restrictions is described in the PHE report .

    HYP: he said : `` Electronic cigarettes are considerably less harmful than smoking . ''

    HYP: one of two lifelong smokers will die because of their addiction .

    HYP: all evidence suggests that health risks posed by electronic cigarettes are small in comparison , but we need to continue to examine the long-term effects .

    HYP: PHE has a clear duty to inform the public about what the evidence shows , and also what they do n't show , especially when there was so much public confusion about relative dangers compared to tobacco .

    HYP: nearly 80,000 people a year die from diseases related to smoking and smoking costs the NHS 2 billion a year .


  1131. REF: by spelling out clearly the current evidence - that while e-cigarettes are not risk-free , they carry only a fraction of the harm caused by smoking - we are fulfilling our national remit .

    HYP: a clear highlight of the current evidence - that even if e-cigarettes are not without risks , bear only a fraction of the damage caused by smoking - we are fulfilling our national competence .


  1132. REF: BBC should give up EastEnders , says former Channel 4 chief

    HYP: BBC should quit with EastEnders , says former director of Channel 4


  1133. REF: the former Channel 4 chairman Luke Johnson has said the BBC should stop broadcasting programmes such as EastEnders and The Voice , saying its commercial rivals would `` give their right arm '' for hit shows such as the Albert Square soap .

    HYP: the former director of Channel 4 , Luke Johnson , said the BBC should stop broadcast programmes such as EastEnders and The Voice , and confirmed that its commercial rivals would `` give the right hand '' for a hit show such as Albert Square .


  1134. REF: Johnson said the licence fee should only be used to make the sort of programmes that are not made by other UK broadcasters .

    HYP: Johnson said the licence fee should only be used for programs not made by other British television broadcasters .


  1135. REF: he criticised the BBC for putting public service programmes likely to be watched by a smaller audience in tough slots against its rivals '' biggest rating shows , and on channels such as BBC4 .

    HYP: he criticised the BBC for putting public service programs likely to be watched by only a handful of people , into complex broadcasting times over its rivals `` biggest ratings show , and on channels such as BBC4 .


  1136. REF: after the BBC 's director general , Tony Hall , said the corporation wanted to do more in partnership with other organisations , Johnson said he had tried for six years in his time at Channel 4 to do a tie-up with the BBC without success .

    HYP: after Generally Director Tony Hall said the corporation wanted to do more in partnership with other organisations , Johnson said he had unsuccessfully tried to connect with the BBC for the entire six years he worked on Channel 4 .


  1137. REF: `` I do struggle with the idea that the BBC commissions and broadcasts programmes that would clearly be shown by unsubsidised rivals , '' Johnson told the House of Lords communication committee , as part of its inquiry into the future of the BBC .

    HYP: `` I struggle with the idea that the BBC backs up and sends out programs that would certainly be broadcast by rivals without the state 's contributions , '' Johnson said in the Communications Commission in the Upper House , as part of the negotiations on the BBC 's future .


  1138. REF: if you keep the licence fee , which I 'm not sure in the medium or long term is a good idea , it should reduce its output at least to programmes that others are n't making and commissioning .

    HYP: if you retain the royalties I am not sure about whether they are a good idea in the medium or long term , the production should be reduced at least in terms of programmes that do not produce or exclude others .


  1139. REF: they broadcast The Voice in a prime slot because they want to gain as broad a support as possible for its future .

    HYP: they broadcast The Voice in the main broadcasting time because they want to get the widest possible support into the future .


  1140. REF: the idea that no one else would show that is a joke , it 's ludicrous , it 's obviously nonsense .

    HYP: the idea that no one else would broadcast it is a ridiculous joke , and of course meaningless .


  1141. REF: Johnson said : `` I do n't see why a regressive tax should fund programmes that could be funded without subsidy .

    HYP: Johnson said : `` I do n't understand why the regressive tax should support programs that can be funded by no-contributor .


  1142. REF: the Voice is one , EastEnders is another , admittedly made in-house .

    HYP: the Voice is one of them , EastEnders next , and understandably produced on home soil .


  1143. REF: frankly other channels would give their right arm for it .

    HYP: honestly , other channels would give their right hand for them .


  1144. REF: I struggle to see how it 's public service broadcasting .

    HYP: I ca n't understand how these public broadcasting services are .


  1145. REF: I do n't think that would diminish the BBC at all .

    HYP: I do n't think it would weaken the BBC in the slightest .


  1146. REF: Johnson , a serial entrepreneur who led Channel 4 from 2004 to 2010 , said the BBC was guilty of chasing ratings `` because of the ambitions of people who work there , and because they believe that is the best way to secure long-term support . ''

    HYP: Johnson , an entrepreneur in the series that led Channel 4 from 2004 to 2010 , told the BBC he felt vindicated by gaining ratings `` because of the ambitions of the people who worked here , and because he believed it was the best way to secure long-term support . ''


  1147. REF: his comments about the BBC 's most popular shows echo those of former Sky executive Tony Ball , who used his MacTaggart lecture in Edinburgh in 2003 to propose that the BBC sell off shows such as EastEnders .

    HYP: his comment on the BBC 's most popular show repeats those former executive director Sky , Tony Ball , who used his Mactaggart lesson in Edinburgh in 2003 to suggest the BBC will sell the show as EastEnders .


  1148. REF: Johnson said the BBC 's more niche public service programmes `` go on to BBC4 where quite often you ca n't measure the audience but they fulfil their remit and they can argue when they go on their sanctimonious missions about justifying 4bn in licence fee income , `` Well of course , we do all these obscure programmes that no one watched . ''

  1149. REF: they put them on a slot where no one was ever going to watch them .

    HYP: they broadcast them at a time when no one is looking at them .


  1150. REF: on the licence fee , Johnson told the committee : `` I challenge you to find a more regressive system in terms of who gets the best value from it .

    HYP: as for the licence fee , Johnson told the committee : `` I call on you to find a regressive system about who gets the best value from it .


  1151. REF: of course you all think , we all think , 150 a year is great value , but for people for whom 150 is a lot of money I wonder if they do because they do n't consume a lot of the BBC .

    HYP: of course , we all think that 150 British pounds a year is a big sum , but for people , for whom 150 is a lot , I would be surprised if they pay so much , because they do n't look at the BBC so much .

    HYP: the former director of Sky and Channel 5 , David Elstein , who stepped down before the commission on Tuesday , said the BBC should revise its reigning mission in terms of `` informing , educating and entertaining . ''


  1153. REF: he said little of the BBC 's output was now formally classified as education - he said it was 1 % of its TV output and 0.1 % on radio - and it should take a lead from public service broadcasters in Australia and Canada and change it to `` inform , enlighten and entertain . ''

    HYP: he confirmed that a small volume of BBC production has now been classified as educational - it used to be 1 % television production and 0.1 % on radio - and should take on a pattern of public public broadcasting in Australia and Canada and change to `` inform , clarify and entertain . ''

    HYP: on the subject of the partnership , Elstein said the BBC should do more in areas like the Proms , which only a handful were sent off on television , and to connect with commercial reporters so that we can all see them online .


  1155. REF: 'Sonogenetics ' allows brain cells to be controlled by sound waves

    HYP: `` Sonogenetics '' or control of brain cells by sound waves


  1156. REF: the video shows how the nematodes change direction the moment they are blasted with sonic pulses .

    HYP: this video shows how sound impulses influence the direction the patrols are moving .


  1157. REF: scientists have bred worms with genetically modified nervous systems that can be controlled by bursts of sound waves .

    HYP: scientists have raised worms with a genetically modified nervous system that can control sound waves .


  1158. REF: the tiny nematodes change direction the moment they are blasted with sonic pulses that are too high-pitched for humans to hear .

    HYP: tiny patrols change direction by the time they are hit by sound impulses that are inaudible to the human ear .


  1159. REF: the pulses work by switching on motor neuron cells that are genetically modified to carry membrane channels that respond to ultrasonic waves .

    HYP: the pulses work by switching the cells of genetically modified motor neurons that are programmed to respond to these ultrasonic waves .


  1160. REF: related : researchers read and write brain activity with light

    HYP: related : scientists can read and write brain activity by light


  1161. REF: researchers said the worms demonstrate the power of a new procedure , dubbed sonogenetics , in which ultrasound can be used to activate a range of brain , heart and muscle cells from outside the body .

    HYP: the scientists said these worms are a great demonstration of a new methodology called sonogenetics , which uses ultrasound to activate brain , heart and muscle cells and activates outside the body .


  1162. REF: Sreekanth Chalasani , a researcher at the Salk Institute in La Jolla , California , told the Guardian that the procedure could one day replace deep-brain stimulation , an invasive procedure that delivers electrical pulses into people 's brains to treat symptoms of Parkinson 's disease .

    HYP: Sreekanth Chalasani , a researcher at the Salk Institute in La Jolla in California , said for the Guardian that this method could one day replace deep brain stimulation - an invasive procedure in which electrodes that stimulate the brain are implanted in the brain . the method is used , for example , to treat the symptoms of Parkinson 's disease .


  1163. REF: nematode worms do not usually react to ultrasound , but Chalasani found that they did when they were surrounded by a fluid containing microscopic bubbles .

    HYP: polishes usually do not respond to ultrasound , but Chalasani found that the reaction occurs when placed in a liquid containing microscopic bubbles .


  1164. REF: the bubbles , he found , amplify the ultrasonic waves which then pass inside the worms .

    HYP: as he discovered , bubbles amplify ultrasonic waves that then pass through the body of worms .


  1165. REF: the amplified ultrasound waves act on structures called TRP-4 ion channels , found in the membranes of some of the worms '' cells .

    HYP: enhanced ultrasonic waves operate in the ion channel TRP-4 , which is located in the membranes of some worm cells .


  1166. REF: the sound waves make these ion channels open up and activate the cells they are attached to , according to a report in Nature Communications .

    HYP: thanks to the sound waves , these channels are opening up and activating the cells they are associated with , the report says in the journal Nature Communications .


  1167. REF: to make ultrasound-controlled nematodes , Chalasani genetically modified the worms so that some of their motor neurons carried TRP-4 ion channels .

    HYP: to control the tubers using ultrasonic waves , Chalasani genetically modified the worms so that some of their motor neurons contain the ion channels of TRP-4 .


  1168. REF: when he applied ultrasound to the modified creatures , the sound waves were amplified by the microbubbles and transmitted into the worms , where they switched on the modified motor neurons .

    HYP: when then used on such modified worms , the sound waves were amplified by microbubbles and carried to worms , where modified motor neurons were switched on .


  1169. REF: the procedure has some similarities with optogenetics , a groundbreaking tool that allows scientists to switch neurons on and off with pulses of light .

    HYP: the new method is akin to optogenetics , a pioneering tool that allows scientists to turn on and switch neurons through the light .


  1170. REF: but Chalasani said that sonogenetics could have some advantages over that technique .

    HYP: but Chalasani said that sonogenetics could have many advantages over this technique .


  1171. REF: unlike light , which has to be sent down an optic fibre to the desired location inside the brain , low frequency ultrasound waves can pass through tissue unhindered , and so can be sent into the brain from on top of the skull .

    HYP: unlike the light , which must be sprinkled with optical fibre to the required site in the brain , ultrasonic waves can penetrate the tissues without restriction and be sent directly to the brain .


  1172. REF: `` We believe that , using gene therapy and a therapeutic virus , it may be possible to make target human neurons temporarily susceptible to the ultrasound signal in a clinical setting for certain neurological treatments , '' said Chalasani .

    HYP: `` We believe that when we use gene therapy and therapeutic viruses , we can target human neurons and make them temporarily sensitive to ultrasound signals used in clinical treatment to treat neurological diseases , '' Chalasani said .


  1173. REF: other applications could focus on muscle cells and insulin-producing cells , he added .

    HYP: he added that the method would also be found in the treatment of muscle cells and insulin-producing cells .

    HYP: an illegal torture device - right on your doorstep !

  1692. REF: there are a thousand ways to kill time , but none to revive it .

    HYP: there are thousands of ways to kill time , but no way to resurrect it .


  1693. REF: a little knowledge is a dangerous thing . so is a lot .

    HYP: knowing little is dangerous and knowing too much .


  1694. REF: if I were given an hour in which to do a problem upon which my life depended , I would spend 40 minutes studying it , 15 minutes reviewing it and 5 minutes solving it .

    HYP: if I had an hour to master the problem my life depended on , I would spend 40 minutes of his study , 15 minutes of his analysis and 5 minutes of his solution .


  1695. REF: the hardest thing in the world to understand is income taxes .

    HYP: in the world the hardest thing to understand the income tax .


  1696. REF: to close , I ca n't not quote Einstein 's formula for the definition of success : if we take A as success , the following equation applies : A=X+Y+Z , where X is work , Y is rest and Z is to hold your tongue .

    HYP: at the end of the day , I can not forgive myself for failing to guide Einstein 's definition of success : by taking A for success , the formula is : and = X + Y + Z , where X is a work , Y rest , and Z is to keep its mouth shut .


  1697. REF: new and modern .

    HYP: new and modern .

    HYP: hospitals in the Zln region are expecting changes in 1.5 billion .

    HYP: `` It 's a success considering that all of this year , all four are held in black numbers , '' said contender Stanislav Mik .

    HYP: the total profit of regional facilities is about $ 32 million at this time .

    HYP: even this fact shows that after poor years , hospitals can finally afford more investment .

    HYP: more comfort for patients .

    HYP: the interior minister , Milan Chovanec ( SSD ) , has complained after negotiations with his European colleagues that the other states of the Czech Republic are pushing to adopt quotas for refugee redistribution , but reject any discussion .


  1744. REF: he also adds that nobody has yet explained how he is to keep allocated refugees in the Czech Republic when they do n't want to live there anyway .

    HYP: he also observes that he has not yet been told how he should keep the allocated refugees in the Czech Republic when they do not want to live with us anyway .


  1745. REF: `` We did n't get an answer , and we therefore requested that quotas were left out of the final text , '' said Chovanec to journalists .

    HYP: `` We did n't get the answer , and that 's why we wanted the quotas to be released from the final text , '' Chovanec told reporters .


  1746. REF: could you describe more specifically the position that you took into the meeting of EU foreign and interior ministers ?

    HYP: can you , more specifically , describe the position you came to be at the meeting of the EU 's foreign ministers and the European Union ?


  1747. REF: we do not agree with mandatory quotas or the system , which can not work .

    HYP: we disagree with mandatory quotas as a system that just ca n't function .


  1748. REF: we can not talk about migrants as if they were bags of salt or flour .

    HYP: we ca n't talk about migrants like bags of salt or flour .


  1749. REF: they are living beings who have a vision , are going somewhere , have relatives .

    HYP: they 're living creatures that have some visions , they 're going somewhere , they have some relatives .


  1750. REF: what we wanted to hear from our colleagues was how they would keep migrants on the territory of Member States if they were redistributed .

    HYP: we wanted to hear from colleagues how we were able to keep migrants in the territory of the Member States if they were redistributed .


  1751. REF: we can not imagine this .

    HYP: we ca n't imagine .


  1752. REF: we did n't get an answer , so we requested that quotas be left out of the final text .

    HYP: we did n't get the answer , and that 's why we wanted the quotas to be released from the final text .


  1753. REF: we did not have any problems with the other conclusions from the meeting - functional hotspots , that is registration points , the protection of borders , camps outside Europe , a trust fund for African countries and other matters .

    HYP: with the other conclusions - functional hotspots , registration places , border protection , camps outside Europe , a trust fund for African countries and other things , we have no problem with that .


  1754. REF: we have been speaking about this for a year and think that this is the way forward .

    HYP: we 've been talking about this for a year and we 're saying this is the way .


  1755. REF: but to say that quotas will solve everything ?

    HYP: but saying quotas will solve everything ?


  1756. REF: not long ago we were discussing forty thousand , now it 's one hundred and twenty thousand .

    HYP: we 've done forty grand a little while ago , now it 's a hundred and twenty thousand .


  1757. REF: when will it be five hundred thousand ?

    HYP: when will it be five hundred thousand ?


  1758. REF: and how will we keep those people in our country ?

    HYP: and how do we keep those people in that territory ?


  1759. REF: ninety-eight percent of people who pass through the Czech Republic want to go to Germany .

    HYP: ninety-eight percent of all people crossing us want to go to Germany .


  1760. REF: almost no-one wants to come here , we simply do n't know how to keep them here .

    HYP: there 's almost no one for us , we just do n't know how to hold them here .


  1761. REF: other foreigners , Ukrainians , Vietnamese and others , for whom the Czech Republic is a destination country , have ambitions to come here ; they get asylum - but interest from this wave of migration , that is from Syria and other countries , is virtually zero .

    HYP: we have the ambition to walk by other foreigners , Ukrainians , Vietnamese , and others who take the Czech Republic as a target country , they are gaining asylum on us , but the interest of people from this migratory wave , from Syria and other countries , is limited close to zero .


  1762. REF: you have said that refugees do not want to come to the Czech Republic , but we have already undertaken to accept fifteen hundred people .

    HYP: you mentioned that the refugees do n't actually want us , but fifteen hundred people have already pledged to accept .


  1763. REF: would n't it be possible to accept more this way ?

    HYP: would it not be possible to accept more of them ?


  1764. REF: we undertook to accept fifteen hundred people , but with conditions .

    HYP: we have pledged to accept 1500 people , but with the condition .


  1765. REF: we said : functional hotspots , border protection , military operations .

    HYP: we said : functional hotspots , border protection , military operations .


  1766. REF: what will happen with that 1500 is that 1100 of them will undergo asylum proceedings .

    HYP: even with the 1,500 , there 's going to be 1100 people with whom we can deal with an asylum procedure .


  1767. REF: they will come to our detention facilities and we will treat them the same as the ones we have caught .

    HYP: they will come into our detention facility and treat them as much as to those we have captured .


  1768. REF: it 's a major issue and we 'll discuss with Europe whether we can hold people who are registered in Italy , Greece or Hungary ,

    HYP: it is a big issue , and we will debate it with Europe if we can hold people to be registered in Italy and Greece , possibly in Hungary .


  1769. REF: because Europe 's attitude is that if they 're registered , they ca n't be held .

    HYP: because Europe is behaving in such a way that if they have a registration , they can not be detained .


  1770. REF: this means that , if they enter our territory with registration , and if there 's an agreement , which there is n't yet , it could be that do n't even hold those 1100 on the territory of the Czech Republic and then they leave for Germany once they 've arrived .

    HYP: that means , they will come to our territory with the registrations , and if there is a deal that is not yet , it may be that we will not hold that 1100 in the Czech Republic and they will go back to Germany after arriving .


  1771. REF: if we 're able to hold them for the duration of their asylum proceedings , we will start those proceedings .

    HYP: if we can restrain them for the duration of the asylum procedure , we will deal with them in an asylum procedure .


  1772. REF: if they are citizens of Syria or Eritrea , then according to European statistics 98 percent of them get international protection .

    HYP: if it is the citizens of Syria , Eritrea , almost 98 per cent , according to European statistics , receive international protection .


  1773. REF: then they get documents that allow them to travel in Europe .

    HYP: then they get the papers that will allow them to travel across Europe .


  1774. REF: and I think that these people will then end up in destination countries .

    HYP: and I think these people will end up in the target countries again .


  1775. REF: then there are the four hundred people who 'll be resettled here .

    HYP: then there are four hundred people who will be relocated .


  1776. REF: that 's the second project , which is just starting at the moment , are there we only progressed in that we 're debating with the churches about the possibilities for them finding work , accommodation and so on for them .

    HYP: that 's the second project that 's been breaking up so far , and we 've made progress only by debating the churches about the possibility that they should help them get jobs , accommodation and so on .


  1777. REF: but that 's a very long-term project .

    HYP: but that 's a run for a very long line .


  1778. REF: you said that other countries were n't willing to discuss the matter with us at the ministers ' meeting .

    HYP: you said that at the meeting of ministers with us , the other states were unwilling to discuss .


  1779. REF: is n't it more the case that , not only is the Czech Republic rejecting quotas , it is also not offering solidaristic measures that could unblock the discussion ?

    HYP: but is it not that the Czech Republic only rejects quotas , but offers no solidarity step that would block the debate ?


  1780. REF: and what kind of solidaristic measure should that be , in your opinion ?

    HYP: and what exactly does that take to be a solid step ?


  1781. REF: if the Federal Republic of Germany issues an invitation for all refugees from Syria , that message spreads through all camps in not only Europe , but also Turkey and Jordan in a matter of hours .

    HYP: if the Federal Republic of Germany says an incentive that all migrants from Syria can join them , the message spreads in the hours of all the camps across Europe , but also in Turkey , Jordan .


  1782. REF: it encourages a further wave of immigration towards Germany , because they do n't want to come to the Czech Republic .

    HYP: it encourages another migratory wave that goes to Germany because they just do n't want us to .

    HYP: we think the road is to protect the external borders - just to discourage those migratory waves , to help the needy , and to separate economic migrants .


  1784. REF: to show them unambiguously that they do n't have a chance .

    HYP: to show them that they do n't stand a chance .


  1785. REF: Fifty thousand Kosovars came to Germany last year alone .

    HYP: Fifty thousand Kosovans came to Germany last year alone .

    HYP: from secure Kosovo , where we pay all the saturation of this state , including the police , the courts , the prosecutor 's office .

    HYP: if we could separate them and not accept them or accept them only according to the needs of the economies , that fifty per cent of what social-welfare systems would spend on them today could go to refugees .


  1788. REF: the number of people held in the Czech Republic increased the day after Germany introduced checks .

    HYP: contrary to the first day that Germany had implemented the controls , the number of detainees in the Czech Republic jumped .


  1789. REF: now it 's eighty , and on the first day it was twelve .

    HYP: now it 's eighty , the first day it was 12 .

    HYP: where should it go to tighten controls on the border ?

    HYP: we were afraid of a glitch in the order of hundreds of people .


  1792. REF: these are the numbers that we can manage .

    HYP: these are the numbers we 're managing .

    HYP: we still have a few hundred vacancies in stone detentions .

    HYP: of course , all the people we hold will return to Austria within seven days .


  1795. REF: that 's out standard procedure .

    HYP: we do it by default .


  1796. REF: the Austrians are the only ones who take them from us . with Hungary it 's complicated and the Greeks - that 's something else entirely .

    HYP: the Austrians are the only ones taking these people , with Hungary it 's complex and the Greeks - that 's a completely useless story .


  1797. REF: where is the tipping point ?

    HYP: so where is the breaking point ?


  1798. REF: a thousand a day ?

    HYP: would it have to be a thousand a day ?


  1799. REF: I think it would have to be several hundred a day .

    HYP: I think it would have to be a couple of hundred a day .

    HYP: two hundred , three hundred people a day for two , three consecutive days will exhaust our capacity enough to make contingency plans .

    HYP: then I agreed with the Prime Minister that he would immediately call an extraordinary government .

    HYP: the extreme option is the state of emergency , which has now been declared in some places by Hungary ?

    HYP: I do n't think it can come this far .

    HYP: the Czech Republic would be affected very marginally , almost at all .

    HYP: `` All that was after maturity is paid , '' the Met Office said , adding that it would not be paid only to unrelated or disputed commitments .

    HYP: it is also certain that , in the next few days , the judge will not decide and the proceedings will continue .

    HYP: she gave Slavia for three weeks to send detailed evidence that she actually paid those debts .

    HYP: in turn , there will be an appreciation of all the evidence .

    HYP: the decision is therefore to be expected as early as November .

    HYP: the judge ordered the continuation of the negotiations on the third of November .

    HYP: but the decision will not fall on that meeting , but in writing after it .


  1838. REF: medals awarded to Finns and Austrians .

    HYP: medals for Fines and Austrians .

    HYP: yes , it 's a Chinatown and not a Thai neighborhood .

    HYP: the market / warehouse is the only contact point offering a stunning series of fresh , frozen and dried goods , popular Thai and Asian snacks , and kitchen utensils , furniture , religious and holiday decorations .

    HYP: there is even a car part if you need a bit of motor oil .

    HYP: the store is massive and it will take you over an hour to climb all the alleys .

    HYP: on Tuesday , the Chiefs backed the Senate 's version of the law .

    HYP: the MPs have now agreed on his proposal .

    HYP: the Senate version , which was approved by the House , also envisages that plumbing , plumbing , or public-lighting cables could be stored lengthways below the surface of the pavement .


  1986. REF: saving municipalities money that would be spent on land purchases .

    HYP: municipalities would thus be spared for the purchase of land .

    HYP: municipalities should also not be obliged to take care of road vegetation along local roads , regardless of owner of the property concerned .

    HYP: the amendment also aims to improve the protection of roads and facilitate the handling of towed vehicles to which owners do not report .

    HYP: the new municipalities may be able to sell towed vehicles which do not subscribe within the six-month period after notification of the departure of their owners .

    HYP: according to the government , this will save money for the introduction of the electronic system .

    HYP: the city paid at least a million extra .

  2321. REF: for mildly obese diabetics , weight loss surgery may be helpful

    HYP: for slightly obese diabetics , weight-loss surgery could be useful


  2322. REF: the benefits of weight loss surgery for mildly obese people with type 2 diabetes can last at least five years , according to a new study .

    HYP: the benefits of losing surgery for slightly obese people with type 2 diabetes may take at least five years , according to a new study .


  2323. REF: it 's still to early to say whether mildly obese people with diabetes live longer after weight loss surgery than those who receive non-surgical treatments , however .

    HYP: however , it is still too early to say whether slightly obese people with type 2 diabetes live longer after surgery to lose weight than those who receive non-surgical treatment .


  2324. REF: `` The mortality data take a long time to show up , '' said Dr. Robin Blackstone , a weight loss surgery expert who wrote an editorial on the new study in JAMA Surgery .

    HYP: `` The mortality data takes a long time to view , '' says Dr. Robin Blackstone , an expert in surgery to lose weight , who wrote an editorial on the new study of JAMA surgery .


  2325. REF: weight loss operations , or bariatric surgery , use various methods to shrink the size of the stomach .

    HYP: surgery to lose weight , bariatric surgery is used to reduce the stomach 's various methods .


  2326. REF: they reduce hunger and limit the body 's ability to absorb food .

    HYP: reducing hunger and limiting the human body to absorb food .


  2327. REF: over the years , bariatric surgeries have proved effective for treating type 2 diabetes , but most studies were done in people who are morbidly obese , with a body mass index ( BMI ) of 35 or above .

    HYP: over the years , bariatric surgery has proved effective for treating type 2 diabetes , but most of the survey was performed on people with morbid obesity with a body mass index ( BMI ) of 25 or higher .


  2328. REF: BMI , a measure of weight in relation to height , is considered normal between 18.5 and 24.9 .

    HYP: BMI , which measures the relationship weight relative to height , is considered normal in values between 18.5 and 24.9 .


  2329. REF: a BMI of 25 or higher indicates that someone is overweight , and people with a BMI over 30 are considered obese .

    HYP: a BMI of 25 or higher suggests overweight people and people with a value above 30 are seen as obese .


  2330. REF: you can calculate your BMI here : 1.usa.gov/1D0ZqDv .

    HYP: you can calculate your BMI here : 1.usa.gov / 1D0ZqDv .


  2331. REF: for the new study , researchers from Taiwan 's Min-Sheng General Hospital used data collected since 2007 in a trial comparing two kinds of bariatric surgery - gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy - to medical treatments for type 2 diabetes in people who were mildly obese .

    HYP: for their new studies , researchers from the General Hospital of Min-Sheng in Taiwan used data collected from a study since 2007 , which deals with two types of bariatric surgery - gastric bypass and gastrectomy - in the treatment procedures of type-3 diabetes in people who were slightly obese .


  2332. REF: the average BMI among those who had surgery fell from 31 to 24.5 by the end of their fifth year in the study .

    HYP: average BMI among those who underwent surgery declined according to a study from 31 to 24.5 towards the end of their fifth year .


  2333. REF: meanwhile , the BMI among those receiving non-surgical diabetes treatments stayed about the same at 29 .

    HYP: meanwhile , BMI of those was not given surgical treatment of diabetes , roughly the same at 29 .


  2334. REF: among those who had surgery , diabetes resolved completely in 36 percent and partially in 28 percent .

    HYP: among patients with surgery , diabetes was resolved completely in 36 percent and in part in 28 cases .


  2335. REF: in the medically-treated group , by comparison , diabetes resolved completely in only 1 percent and partially in only about 2 percent .

    HYP: in the drugs treated to the group , it was only up to 1 per cent for comparing diabetes and in part to only about 2 per cent of patients .


  2336. REF: in addition , control of blood pressure , triglycerides , and `` bad '' LDL cholesterol `` was generally better in the surgical group , '' the authors found .

    HYP: furthermore , blood pressure control , trigylcerides and `` bad '' LDL cholesterol proved `` generally better in the surgical group , '' the authors found .


  2337. REF: the researchers also monitored patients ' blood levels of hemoglobin A1c , which reflect blood sugar levels over time .

    HYP: the researchers also monitored patient levels of haemoglobin A1c in the blood that reflects the ongoing blood sugar in the body .


  2338. REF: hemoglobin A1c is best kept below 7 percent , the researchers write .

    HYP: hemoglobin A1c is best kept below 7 percent , the researchers report .


  2339. REF: after surgery , the average hemoglobin A1c level fell from about 9 percent to about 6 percent .

    HYP: after the operation , the average haemoglobin of A1c fell from about 9 per cent to about 6 per cent .


  2340. REF: in the medical therapy group , however , it remained steady at about 8 percent .

    HYP: however , this value remained at about 8 per cent in the treatment group .


  2341. REF: but this better `` glycemic control '' - as reflected by the improved hemoglobin A1c levels - did not reduce the mortality rate at five years , according to lead researcher Dr. Chih-cheng Hsu and colleagues .

    HYP: but this better `` glycaemic control '' - which is reflected in better levels of haemoglobin A1c - did not reduce mortality in five years , according to chief researcher Dr Chih-cheng Hsu and his colleagues .


  2342. REF: the research team also compared average outcomes with the two types of surgery .

    HYP: the research team also compared average results with two types of operations .


  2343. REF: at the fifth year , compared to the sleeve gastrectomy group , the bypass surgery group had lost more weight ( 18.7 vs 14.2 kg ) , achieved larger drops in BMI ( 7.4 vs 5.1 ) and in hemoglobin A1c ( 3.1 percent vs 2.1 percent ) and were more likely to have complete diabetes remission ( 46.9 percent vs 16.7 percent ) .

    HYP: after the fifth year , the group lost more weight compared to a group of gastrectomy ( 18.7 against 14.2 kg ) , reaching larger drops of BMI ( 7,4 against 5.1 ) and haemoglobin of A1c ( 3.1 percent against 2.1 percent ) and were more likely to remission diabetes ( 46.9 percent against 16.7 percent ) .


  2344. REF: while the new study does not show a survival benefit or surgery after five years , there is evidence from a study of heavier people in Sweden that surgery does lead to a longer life , says Blackstone , of the University of Arizona College of Medicine-Phoenix .

    HYP: while the new study does not show improvement in survival or surgery after five years , there is evidence from the study of stronger people in Sweden , where they found that surgery leads to an extension of life , says Blackstone from the University of Arizona College or Medicine-Phoenix .


  2345. REF: in the Swedish study , obese people who had bariatric surgery were about 29 percent less likely to die over 15 years , compared to a group who tried more conventional methods .

    HYP: according to the Swedish study , obese people who underwent bariatric surgery about a 29 percent greater chance of survival over the next 15 years , compared with a group that tried more conventional methods .


  2346. REF: though the new study did n't show a benefit in survival among surgery patients , Blackstone said it 's reassuring for people with a BMI under 35 interested in the procedure .

    HYP: though a new study has not shown improvements in survival among patients after surgery , according to Blackstone , it 's a reassuring result for people with a BMI under 35 who are interested in these procedures .


  2347. REF: `` This is where this paper is critical , because it says this surgery is safe in that lower BMI group , '' with no increased risk of death or renal disease , she said .

    HYP: `` This is where this work is critical because it states that surgery is safer in a group with lower BMI , '' without increasing the risk of death or kidney disease , it states .


  2348. REF: Blackstone added that people and their doctors should start taking weight seriously once the patient 's BMI falls between 27 and 30 .

    HYP: the European Union decided on Monday to address the problem of refugees : it will be more systematically sorting out migrants and asylum seekers once they enter the old continent - especially in Greece , rather than arguing for the future distribution of refugees under quotas on the basis of quantities that are increasingly distant from reality .

    HYP: in the news , it will not initially propose a minimum $ 4 million limit for travel agents offering tours of air travel , and a million-dollar limit for office selling , for example , bus tours .


  2845. REF: the limit will remain at 30 percent of planned takings from the sale of tours .

    HYP: the border will remain at 30 per cent of planned sales from sales of tours .


  2846. REF: however , the insurance limit will have to be such that travel agencies can cover the entirety of clients ' claims in the event of bankruptcy .

    HYP: however , the premium performance limit will need to be such that , in the event of bankruptcy , the travel agent will cover all customer claims .


  2847. REF: even after these modifications the law will require that tour operators now state which travel agency is organising tours that have been sold .

    HYP: the standard , even after adjustments , stipulates that the travel agencies will need to re-list the travel agencies for the trip to which the tour operator organises the trip .

    HYP: travel agents will have to submit to insurance companies before closing the contract , among other data on the management and number of tours .

    HYP: the approved amendment of the Public Accounts Committee also provides for further regular information by the insurance companies .

    HYP: travel agents will have to supply them each month with data on the number of passengers and sold-out tours , the total cost of the tours and the amount of advances and sales for the tours and the vouchers for them .


  2851. REF: should the Ministry of Regional Development find that a travel agency has not met a legal obligation towards an insurance company , it will , according to the proposal , request that the agency remedy the situation or will be permitted to bar it from agreeing new contracts in the event that such a breach of its obligations could threaten the interests of customers .

    HYP: if the Ministry of Local Development finds that the travel agent has not complied with any of the legal obligations to the insurance company , it will invite it , according to the draft , or it will be able to prohibit it from entering into new contracts if a breach of the obligation could jeopardise the interests of customers .

    HYP: the amendment also has to re-edit the funding of the mountain service .

    HYP: since August 20 , however , he has not yet played for the outstretched muscle .
